review.title: ILexicOn: toward an ECD-compliant interlingual lexical ontology described with semantic web formalisms
review.abstract: We are interested in bridging the world of natural language and the world of the semantic web in particular to support natural multilingual access to the web of data. In this paper we introduce a new type of lexical ontology called interlingual lexical ontology (ILexicOn), which uses semantic web formalisms to make each interlingual lexical unit class (ILUc) support the projection of its semantic decomposition on itself. After a short overview of existing lexical ontologies, we briefly introduce the semantic web formalisms we use. We then present the three layered architecture of our approach: i) the interlingual lexical meta-ontology (ILexiMOn); ii) the ILexicOn where ILUcs are formally defined; iii) the data layer. We illustrate our approach with a standalone ILexicOn, and introduce and explain a concise human-readable notation to represent ILexicOns. Finally, we show how semantic web formalisms enable the projection of a semantic decomposition on the decomposed ILUc.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we present the core of the ongoing ULiS project, which is at the center of Meaning-Text Theory (MTT), pivot-based NLP techniques, and semantic web formalisms. What we are striving for in the ULiS project is a universal linguistic system (ULiS) through which multiple actors with interlingual knowledge bases can interact in multiple controlled (i.e. limited and formal) natural languages. Any controlled natural language (dictionary, grammar rules) would be described in a part of a universal linguistic knowledge base (ULK). In addition, the ULK consists of a specific interlingual knowledge base.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and discussions
sections.text: We introduced and illustrated a three-layered architecture that describes ECD-compliant interlingual lexical ontologies using semantic web formalisms; we introduced the core of an interlingual lexical meta-ontology (ILexiMOn) that constitutes the top level of architecture; this ILexiMOn describes the interlingual lexical ontology called ILexicOn, which describes classes of interlingual lexical units (ILUcs); and finally, interlingual semantic representations are part of the third layer. We introduced a novel approach to the formal definition of ILUcs: we let ILUcs support a projection of their semantic decomposition, keeping their definition in the same conceptual layer of representation; we introduced a humanly readable notation to represent ILexicOn, and we used this notation to illustrate our approach with a simple lexical model.
